abstract.para: Nodes in &cloud; are automatically installed from the &admserv;. For this to happen, software repositories containing products, extensions, and the respective updates for all software need to be available on or accessible from the &admserv;. In this configuration step, these repositories are made available. There are two types of repositories:

Product Media Repositories: Product media repositories are copies of the installation media. They need to be directly copied to the &admserv;, loop-mounted from an iso image, or mounted from a remote server via NFS. Affected are &cloudos; and &productname; &productnumber;. These are static repositories; they do not change or receive updates. See for setup instructions.

Update and Pool Repositories: Update and Pool repositories are provided by the &scc;. They contain all updates and patches for the products and extensions. To make them available for &cloud; they need to be mirrored from the &scc;. Since their content is regularly updated, they must be kept in synchronization with &scc;. For these purposes, &suse; provides either the &smtool; (⪪) or the &susemgr;.

sect1.title: Copying the Product Media Repositories
sect1.para: The files in the product repositories for &sls; and &cloud; do not change, therefore they do not need to be synchronized with a remote source. It is sufficient to either copy the data (from a remote host or the installation media), to mount the product repository from a remote server via NFS, or to loop mount a copy of the installation images.

important.title: No Symbolic Links for the &sls; Repository
important.para: Note that the &sls; product repository must be directly available from the local directory listed below. It is not possible to use a symbolic link to a directory located elsewhere, since this will cause booting via PXE to fail.

tip.title: Providing the &productname; Repository via HTTP
tip.para: The &sls; product repositories need to be available locally to enable booting via PXE for node deployment. The &productname; repository may also be served via HTTP from a remote host. In this case, enter the URL to the Cloud repository as described in .

We recommend copying the data to the &admserv; as the best solution. It does not require much hard disk space (approximately &mediaspace;). Nor does it require the &admserv; to access a remote host from a different network.

sect1.title: Update and Pool Repositories
sect1.para: Update and Pool Repositories are required on the &admserv; to set up and maintain the &cloud; nodes. They are provided by &scc; and contain all software packages needed to install &cloudos; and the extensions (pool repositories). In addition, they contain all updates and patches (update repositories). Update repositories are used when deploying the nodes that build &cloud; to ensure they are initially equipped with the latest software versions available.
The repositories can be made available on the &admserv; using one or more of the following methods:

sect2.title: Repositories Hosted on an ⪪ Server Installed on the &admserv;
sect2.para: When all update and pool repositories are managed by an ⪪ server installed on the &admserv; (see ), make sure the repository location in &yast; &crow; is set to Local SMT Server (this is the default). For details, see . No further action is required. The &inst_crow; automatically detects all available repositories.

sect2.title: Repositories Hosted on a Remote ⪪ Server
sect2.para: To use repositories from a remote ⪪ server, you first need to make sure all required repositories are mirrored on the server. Refer to for more information. When all update and pool repositories are managed by a remote ⪪ server, make sure the repository location in &yast; &crow; is set to Remote SMT Server. For details, see . No further action is required. The &inst_crow; automatically detects all available repositories.

note.title: Accessing an External ⪪ Server
note.para: When using an external ⪪ server, it needs to be reachable by all nodes. This means that the ⪪ server either needs to be part of the admin network or it needs to be accessible via the default route of the nodes. The latter can be either the gateway of the admin network or the gateway of the public network.

sect2.title: Repositories Hosted on a &susemgr; Server
sect2.para: To use repositories from &susemgr; you first need to make sure all required products and extensions are registered, and the corresponding channels are mirrored in &susemgr; (refer to for a list of channels).

important.title: Accessing a &susemgr; Server
important.para: An external &susemgr; server needs to be accessible to all nodes in &cloud;. The network hosting the &susemgr; server must be added to the network definitions as described in .

sect2.para: By default &susemgr; does not expose repositories for direct access. To access them via HTTPS, you need to create a Distribution for auto-installation for the &cloudos; (x86_64) product. Creating this distribution makes the update repositories for this product available, including the repositories for all registered add-on products (like &productname;, &slsa; &hasi; and &storage;). Instructions for creating a distribution are in the &susemgr; documentation in .

During the distribution setups you need to provide a Label for each the distribution. This label will be part of the URL under which the repositories are available. We recommend choosing a name consisting of characters that do not need to be URL-encoded. In we assume the following label has been provided: sles12-sp3-x86_64.

When all update and pool repositories are managed by a &susemgr; server, make sure the repository location in &yast; &crow; is set to SUSE Manager Server. For details, see . No further action is required. The &inst_crow; automatically detects all available repositories.

The autoinstallation tree provided by &susemgr; does not provide the &slsa; Pool repository. Although this repository is not used for node installation, it needs to be present. To work around this issue, it is sufficient to create an empty Pool repository for &cloudos;:

sect2.title: Alternative Ways to Make the Repositories Available
sect2.para: If you want to keep your &cloud; network as isolated from the company network as possible, or your infrastructure does not allow accessing a &susemgr; or an ⪪ server, you can alternatively provide access to the required repositories by one of the following methods:

listitem.para: Mount the repositories from a remote server.
Synchronize the repositories from a remote server (for example via rsync and cron).
Manually synchronize the update repositories from removable media.

sect2.para: We strongly recommended making the repositories available at the default locations on the &admserv; as listed in . When choosing these locations, it is sufficient to set the repository location in &yast; &crow; to Custom. You do not need to specify a detailed location for each repository. Refer to for details. If you prefer to use different locations, you need to announce each location with &yast; &crow;.

sect1.title: Software Repository Sources for the &admserv; Operating System
sect1.para: During the installation of the &admserv;, repository locations for &cloudos; are automatically added to the &admserv;. They point to the source used to install the &admserv; and to the &scc;. These repository locations have no influence on the repositories used to set up nodes in the cloud. They are solely used to maintain and update the &admserv; itself.

However, as the &admserv; and all nodes in the cloud use the same operating system—&cloudos;—it makes sense to use the same repositories for the cloud and the &admserv;. To avoid downloading the same patches twice, change this setup so that the repositories set up for &cloud; deployment are also used on the &admserv;.

To do so, you need to disable or delete all services. In a second step all &sls; and &cloud; repositories need to be edited to point to the alternative sources. Use either Zypper or &yast; to edit the repository setup. Note that changing the repository setup on the &admserv; is optional.
